qas.question: Who wrote 'Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge'?
When was 'Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge' published?
Whom did Locke claim created order?

context: A generation later, the <a3_0>Irish<a3_0/> <a2_0><b6_0>Anglican<b6_0/><a2_0/> bishop, <a0_0><a4_0>George Berkeley<a4_0/><a0_0/> (1685–1753), determined that Locke's view immediately opened a door that would lead to eventual atheism. In response to <b7_0>Locke<b7_0/>, he put forth in his Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge (<a1_0><b5_0>1710<b5_0/><a1_0/>) an important challenge to empiricism in which things only exist either as a result of their being perceived, or by virtue of the fact that they are an entity doing the perceiving. (For Berkeley, God fills in for humans by doing the perceiving whenever humans are not around to do it.) In his text Alciphron, Berkeley maintained that any order humans may see in nature is the language or handwriting of <b8_0>God<b8_0/>. Berkeley's approach to empiricism would later come to be called subjective idealism.
